sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Peterson JC, Freeman DH; Int J Env Anal Chem 18: 237-52 (1984)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Diallyl phthalate was detected at 2 of 7 sites on the Chester River, MD which flows into Chesapeake Bay. The sites were located below a plasticizer manufacturing plant. Samples were collected in June, 1978(1).

plant_translocations.content: This study focused on investigating the dissipation, uptake, translocation, and accumulation of various phthalic acid esters (PAEs), including diallyl phthalate (DAP), diisobutyl phthalate (DIBP), dibutyl phthalate (DBP), benzyl butyl phthalate (BBP), and di-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP), in the sediment-Zizania latifolia system. The dissipation rates of PAEs in the sediment exhibited a positive correlation with exposure time, with over 68.12% reduction observed after 28 days, even under high initial concentrations. All five PAEs were taken up by the roots from contaminated sediment, translocated into stems and leaves, and their content in each tissue showed significant linear correlations with the sediment content. DEHP demonstrated the highest transportation from sediment to roots and stems, followed by BBP, DBP, DIBP, and DAP, while the order of transportation from roots to leaves was reversed. Throughout the 28-day exposure, the average concentration of each PAE in stems was the highest, followed by roots, leaves, and edible parts. DEHP and BBP were identified as major contaminants in edible parts but were deemed safe for human health. The accumulation of PAEs in edible parts was influenced by various factors, including PAE species and concentration, survival time, and harvest time of edible parts. The study highlighted the potential of Zizania latifolia not only as a safe food source but also as a promising plant for remediating contaminated sediment by accumulating and degrading PAEs from the environment.
plant_translocations.reference: Zhang, D., Zhou, K., Liu, C., Li, X., Pan, S., & Zhong, L. (2023). Dissipation, uptake, translocation and accumulation of five phthalic acid esters in sediment-Zizania latifolia system. Chemosphere, 315, 137651.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Transplanted to earthenware tanks (45 cm diameter × 30 cm height) each filled with 32 kg of soil. Soil contained 14.52 g/kg of organic matter, 201.41 mg/kg of available potassium, 50.57 mg/kg of available phosphorus, 34.06 mg/kg of available hydrolysis nitrogen and pH was 6.09.
method.Chemical Preparation: Analytical standards (purity greater than 98%) of the investigated phthalic acid esters (PAEs) and anhydrous magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) were obtained. Methanol, acetonitrile, and sodium chloride (NaCl) were analytically pure. Graphitized carbon black (GCB) and ethylenediamine-N-propyl silane (PSA) were also used.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Four spiking levels of PAEs in acetone were spiked to 16 containers to make the total amount of each PAE in each container 0 (Control group), 25 mg (T1 group), 500 mg (T2 group), and 10,000 mg (T3 group). Root concentration factor (RCF) = Croot/Csedi, stem concentration factor (SCF) = Cstem/Csedi, leaf concentration factor (LCF) = Cleaf/Csedi, Translocation factor(TF) stem = Cstem/Croot; Translocation facrot (TF) leaf = Cleaf/Croot
method.Other Information: Four containers were set as a group for each spiking level. In each container, a Z. latifolia plant of similar size was planted.

plant_translocations.result: [{"Treatment Group": "T1", "Root Concentration Factor": 1.6, "Stem Concentration Factor": 1.5, "Leaf Concentration Factor": 2.6, "Translocation Factor Stem": 1.0, "Translocation Factor Leaf": 1.9}, {"Treatment Group": "T2", "Root Concentration Factor": 1.1, "Stem Concentration Factor": 1.3, "Leaf Concentration Factor": 2.2, "Translocation Factor Stem": 1.0, "Translocation Factor Leaf": 1.7}, {"Treatment Group": "T3", "Root Concentration Factor": 0.12, "Stem Concentration Factor": 0.11, "Leaf Concentration Factor": 0.05, "Translocation Factor Stem": 0.6, "Translocation Factor Leaf": 0.3}]
